===Italy=== * [[Adriatic LNG terminal|Adriatic LNG Terminal]], offshore near [[Rovigo]]. Operated [[ExxonMobil]] (45%), [[Qatar Petroleum]] (45%), [[Edison S.p.A.|Edison SpA]] (10%). Entered service in 2009, total storage capacity of 500,000 m<sup>3</sup>, 1 jetty, and a [[regasification]] capacity of 6,486,000,000 m<sup>3</sup> per year. * {{ill|Panigaglia LNG Terminal|it|Rigassificatore di Panigaglia}}, near [[La Spezia]]. Operated by {{ill|GNL Italia|it|Gnl Italia}}, a subsidiary of [[Snam]]. Entered service in 1971, total storage capacity of 100,000 m<sup>3</sup>, 1 jetty, and a regasification capacity of 3,864,000,000 m<sup>3</sup> per year.<ref>{{cite web|title=Panigaglia LNG Terminal|url=http://abarrelfull.wikidot.com/panigaglia-lng-terminal|website=A Barrel Full|accessdate=3 August 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170803222500/http://abarrelfull.wikidot.com/panigaglia-lng-terminal|archivedate=3 August 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * {{ill|Toscana LNG Terminal|it|OLT Offshore LNG Toscana}}, offshore near [[Livorno]]. ==Proposed liquefaction terminals== Need to add Annova LNG and Texas LNG which along with Rio Grande LNG are seeking FERC approval to build and operate at the Port of Brownsville, TX.
Also, NextDecade, parent company of Rio Grande LNG, is seeking DOE permission for a proposed Galveston Bay LNG project.

===North America===
====Canada====
* [[LNG Canada]], Kitimat, B.C. * [[Kitimat LNG]], [[Kitimat]], [[British Columbia]],<ref>[http://www.kitimatlngfacility.com/]</ref> * Pacific NorthWest LNG - [[Progress Energy Resources]] - [[Lelu Island]], [[British Columbia]],<ref>[http://www.progressenergy.com/operations/pacific-northwest-lng/]</ref> * Energie Saguenay - [http://www.energiesaguenay.com] * [[Goldboro LNG]],<ref>[http://www.pieridaeenergy.com/]</ref> [[Pieridae Energy]] - [[Goldboro, NS]]
====United States==== * Alaska LNG (, in Nikiski, AK), in connection with the State's [[Alaska Gasline]] Development Corp * Sabine Pass Liquefaction at Sabine Pass LNG, Louisiana<ref>[http://www.cheniereenergypartners.com/liquefaction_project/liquefaction_project.shtml Sabine Pass LNG Liquefaction, Cheniere Energy Partners Liquefaction Project] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100829161747/http://www.cheniereenergypartners.com/liquefaction_project/liquefaction_project.shtml |date=29 August 2010 }}</ref> * Freeport LNG Dev in Freeport, TX * Cheniere Energy in Corpus Christi, TX * Jordan Cove in Coos Bay, OR (Federal environmental review (EIS) from FERC expected on 30 September 2015.)<ref>{{cite news|title=Jordan Cove LNG's federal environmental review pushed to September|url=http://theworldlink.com/news/local/jordan-cove-lng-s-federal-environmental-review-pushed-to-september/article_d35e7677-38ae-5d14-acde-b10b72993835.html|accessdate=12 June 2015|publisher=The World|date=11 June 2015}}</ref> * Southern Union in Lake Charles, LA * Sempra in Hackberry, LA * Dominion in Cove Point, MD * Oregon LNG in Astoria, OR<ref>[http://ferc.gov/industries/gas/indus-act/lng/LNG-proposed-potential.pdf FERC] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120928100316/http://www.ferc.gov/industries/gas/indus-act/lng/LNG-proposed-potential.pdf |date=28 September 2012 }}</ref> * Jacksonville’s, FLA<ref>http://investors.cleanenergyfuels.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=801521</ref> * Rio Grande LNG in Brownsville, TX<ref>http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160505006666/en/NextDecade-Files-FERC-Application-Reaches-Major-Milestone</ref>
The United States has had a massive shift in LNG terminal planning and construction starting in 2010-2011 due to rapid increase in domestic supply with the widespread adoption of hydraulic fracking. Many brand-new LNG import terminals are planning or have begun addition of liquefaction facilities to operate as export terminals.
===South America===
====Peru====
* [[Peru LNG]], [[Pampa Melchorita]], [[San Vicente de Cañete|Cañete]], [[Peru]]<ref>[http://www.hydrocarbons-technology.com/projects/peru-lng/]</ref>
===Australia===
* [[Barrow Island (Western Australia)|Barrow Island]] - [[Chevron Corporation]] proposes to build an LNG facility and loading terminal on Barrow Island, [[Western Australia]], as part of its Gorgon Project.<ref>[http://www.gorgon.com.au/01gp_project.html gorgon.com.au]</ref> * Australia Pacific LNG - [[Origin Energy]], [[ConocoPhillips]] and [[Sinopec]] - Curtis Island, [[Queensland]].<ref>[http://www.originenergy.com.au/aplng]</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.aplng.com.au/about-project/about-project |title=Archived copy |access-date=27 February 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304220539/http://www.aplng.com.au/about-project/about-project |archive-date=4 March 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * Arrow LNG - [[Arrow Energy]] - Curtis Island, [[Queensland]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arrowenergy.com.au/projects/arrow-lng-plant |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140214063148/http://www.arrowenergy.com.au/projects/arrow-lng-plant |archivedate=14 February 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * [[Gladstone LNG]] - [[Santos Limited|Santos]], [[Petronas]], [[Total S.A.|Total]] and [[KOGAS]] - Curtis Island, [[Queensland]].<ref>[http://www.santosglng.com/]</ref>
===Europe===
* Vassiliko LNG, Limassol, Cyprus
===Russia===
* [[Shtokmann LNG]], [[Murmansk]], [[Russia]] * [[Yamal LNG]], [[Yamal Peninsula|Yamal]], Russia
==Proposed regasification terminals==
===Bangladesh=== *[[Bay of Bengal]] FSRU, [[Maheshkhali Upazila|Maheshkhali]] *Matarbari LNG Terminal, [[Maheshkhali Upazila|Maheshkhali]]
===Croatia=== *[[Adria LNG]]
===Chile=== * GNL Mejillones (In operation) * GNL Quintero (In operation) * GNL Penco
===Colombia===
* Sociedad Portuaria de El Cayao LNG, Cartagena, Bolívar. Planned start of commercial operation Dec-2016
===Estonia=== * Paldiski LNG (developed by [[Alexela]])
===Finland=== * Hamina, owner Hamina LNG (joint venture of Haminan Energia Oy, [[Alexela]] and [[Wärtsilä]])
===France=== *[http://www.fosfaster.com/ Fos-Faster LNG terminal],<ref>{{cite news|title=Fos Faster renonce à son terminal méthanier à Marseille|url=http://www.econostrum.info/Fos-Faster-renonce-a-son-terminal-methanier-a-Marseille_a19602.html|accessdate=20 January 2016|work=Econostrum|date=13 January 2015}}</ref> planned start of commercial operation 2019
===Germany=== *Stade LNG Terminal<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dw.com/de/deutschland-fl%C3%BCssiggas-sucht-hafen-terminal/a-45535867|title=Deutschland: Flüssiggas sucht Hafen-Terminal {{!}} DW {{!}} 18.09.2018|last=(www.dw.com)|first=Deutsche Welle|website=DW.COM|language=de|access-date=2018-09-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.handelsblatt.com/politik/deutschland/gasnetz-offenes-rennen-um-deutschlands-erstes-fluessiggas-terminal/23079402.html|title=Gasnetz: Offenes Rennen um Deutschlands erstes Flüssiggas-Terminal|access-date=2018-09-25|language=de}}</ref> *Brunsbüttel LNG Terminal, to be operated by a joint venture consisting of [[Gasunie]], [[Oiltanking]] and [[Vopak]]. Final decision expected in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=LNG-Terminal für Brunsbüttel|url=https://www.welt.de/regionales/hamburg/article163381788/LNG-Terminal-fuer-Brunsbuettel.html|website=Welt|accessdate=3 August 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170803231444/https://www.welt.de/regionales/hamburg/article163381788/LNG-Terminal-fuer-Brunsbuettel.html|archivedate=3 August 2017|language=German|date=3 April 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=European Commission approves German LNG terminal joint venture|url=http://www.lngworldnews.com/european-commission-approves-german-lng-terminal-joint-venture/|website=LNG World News|accessdate=3 August 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170803231316/http://www.lngworldnews.com/european-commission-approves-german-lng-terminal-joint-venture/|archivedate=3 August 2017|date=12 July 2017|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> *Wilhelmshaven LNG Terminal<ref>{{cite web|title=Zeitung: LNG-Terminal in Wilhelmshaven wieder in Planung|url=http://www.gas-magazin.de/gasmarkt/zeitung-lng-terminal-in-wilhelmshaven-wieder-in-planung_77020.html|website=Gas-Magazin|accessdate=3 August 2017|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170803232043/http://www.gas-magazin.de/gasmarkt/zeitung-lng-terminal-in-wilhelmshaven-wieder-in-planung_77020.html|archivedate=3 August 2017|location=Berlin|language=German|date=20 October 2015|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Greece=== * [[Crete LNG Terminal]], planned * [[Kavala LNG Terminal]], planned
===Hong Kong=== * An FSRU (floating storage regasification unit) in the waters to the east of the [[Soko Islands]]
===India=== *Pipavav LNG Terminal (APM Terminals) *Mundra LNG Terminal (GSPC/[[Adani Group|Adani]]) - 5mt/year<ref name="thehindubusinessline.com"/> *Ennore LNG Terminal Ltd ([[IOCL]]/[[TIDCO]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/lng-terminal-proposed-at-ennore/395930/|title=LNG terminal proposed at Ennore|publisher=business-standard.com|accessdate=2011-06-21|work=}}</ref> *Mangalore LNG Terminal Ltd *Paradwip LNG Terminal ([[GAIL]])-4.8 mt/year<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/gail-to-set-up-rs-3-108-cr-lng-terminal-at-paradip-port-113102600351_1.html | title=GAIL to set up Rs 3,108 cr LNG terminal at Paradip | accessdate=12 February 2014}}</ref> *Kochi LNG Terminal (Puthuvypeen)<ref>http://www.maritime-executive.com/article/india-to-get-its-first-fsru </ref> *Kakinada LNG Terminal owned by GAIL, GDF SUEZ and Shell. 5 mt/year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kostalife.com/news/cm-sets-18-month-deadline-for-making-kakinada-lng-terminal-operational/|title=LNG terminal proposed at Kakinada|accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> *Kakinada LNG Terminal owned by VGS Cavallo, 3.6 mt/year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/andhra-pradesh/Work-on-LNG-terminals-moves-at-a-snail%E2%80%99s-pace/article16086025.ece|title=Work on LNG terminals moves at a snail’s pace|accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> *Kakinada LNG Terminal owned by GMR, 1.75 mt/year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/oil-gas/gmr-to-set-up-an-lng-terminal-at-andhras-kakinada-port-with-a-funding-of-rs-471-crore/articleshow/52386888.cms|title=GMR to set up an LNG terminal at Andhra's Kakinada port|accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> *Vizag LNG Terminal owned by Petronet, 10 mt/year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.yovizag.com/vizag-petroleum-hub/|title=Vizag – Petroleum Hub|accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
===Indonesia=== *East Java by 2011,<ref name="jkpost">http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2010/04/23/gas-shortage-will-continue-until-2015-pgn-says.html</ref> [[Pertamina]] *West Java by 2011,<ref name="jkpost"/> [[Perusahaan Gas Negara|PGN]] and [[Pertamina]] *North Sumatra by 2011<ref name="jkpost"/> by [[Perusahaan Gas Negara|PGN]] ( PT Perusahaan Gas Negara ) The country also has liquefaction terminals in more remote areas for export, and imports from the Middle East in areas with dense population.
===Ireland=== *Shannon LNG Terminal.<ref>[http://www.shannonlngplanning.ie] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110825062213/http://www.shannonlngplanning.ie/ |date=25 August 2011 }}</ref> [[Shannon LNG]]
===Italy=== *Porto Empedocle LNG Terminal
===Japan=== *Hitachi LNG Terminal, [[Tokyo Gas]], 2017 possible start date.
===Latvia=== *A terminal in Riga<ref>http://bnn-news.com/riga-deemed-suitable-place-lng-construction-31700</ref>
===Mexico=== *TGNL - [[Manzanillo, Colima]] scheduled to open 2011{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}{{update inline|date=September 2015}}
===Myanmar=== *A terminal in Kanbauk in [[Tanintharyi Region]] is expected to open in the middle of 2020, through JV of French company [[Total S.A.|Total]] and [[Germany]]’s [[Siemens]] for the 1,230MW capacity in 48 months <ref> [https://frontiermyanmar.net/en/myanmar-bets-on-huge-lng-projects-to-meet-power-needs Myanmar bets on huge LNG projects to meet power needs]</ref> *A terminal in Mee Laung Gyaing in [[Ayeyarwady Region]], is a $2.5 Billion US Dollars JV of [[China]]’s Zhefu and local [[Myanmar]] company [[Supreme Group]] will undertake a 1,390MW [[LNG]] project, with the first phase to be completed in 36 months and full capacity ready in 42 months <ref> [https://www.mmtimes.com/news/total-develop-lng-project-continue-offshore-production-work-myanmar.html Total to develop LNG project, continue offshore production work in Myanmar] </ref> *A terminal in Ahlone in [[Yangon Region]] a [[Thailand]] company TTCL – better known as Toyo Thai to will build a 356MW LNG plant. This is expected to be completed in 28 months <ref> [https://www.reuters.com/article/myanmar-electricity/myanmar-to-double-electricity-capacity-by-2021-to-fill-power-shortages-idUSL4N1PQ2UM Reuters:Myanmar to double electricity capacity by 2021 to fill power shortages]</ref> *A terminal in Kyaukphyu in [[Rakhine State]] a JV of [[China]]’s Sinohydro and [[Myanmar]] Local company [[Supreme Group]] will build another 135MW combined-cycle gas turbine project which is expected to be completed in 28 months with the Ahlone terminal <ref> [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-20/total-in-talks-with-myanmar-to-build-power-plant-and-bring-lng Bloomberg:Total in Talks with Myanmar to Build Power Plant, Supply LNG] </ref>
===Netherlands=== *[[Eemshaven]] LNG Terminal, Eemsmond. Cancelled in 2010.<ref>[http://www.swzonline.nl/news/2339/plans-lng-terminal-eemshaven-cancelled Plans for LNG-Terminal in Eemshaven Cancelled] </ref> *LionGas Terminal, Europoort, Rotterdam. Canceled.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.liongas.nl/?id=24 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724160542/http://www.liongas.nl/?id=24 |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Philippines=== *A [[First Gen LNG Terminal]], Batangas City, Philippines<ref>[http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/01/14/philippines-firstgen-idUKL3N0KO29P20140114 Philippines' First Gen to build US$1 Billion LNG terminal]</ref> *A terminal in [[Sulu]] Southwestern [[Philippines]] in the Island of Mindanao <ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-energyworld-philippines-lng/energy-world-to-kick-off-philippines-lng-terminal-plans-another-idUSKCN1G40TF REUTERS:Energy World to kick off Philippines LNG terminal, plans another] </ref> *A terminal in [[Cebu]] central Philippines of [[Phinma Petroleum and Geothermal]] (PPG), floating storage and regasification unit (FSRU) have already been completed and the entire project is expected to be completed in 2022 <ref>[https://www.lngworldnews.com/phinma-working-on-lng-to-power-project-in-central-philippines Phinma working on LNG-to-power project in Central Philippines]</ref> *Another $1.7 billion US Dollars LNG Terminal to power Luzon to be built by South Korea’s SK E&S with signed MOU with he Korean Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy and the Philippines Department of Energy signed during the visit of the Philippine President [[Rodrigo Roa Duterte]] in South Korea <ref>[https://www.lngworldnews.com/sk-es-plans-to-build-1-7-billion-lng-infrastructure-in-philippines PSK E&S plans to build $1.7 billion LNG infrastructure in Philippines]</ref>
===Russia=== [[Kaliningrad LNG Terminal]]<ref>[http://verslas.lrytas.lt/energetika/gazprom-nutare-gelbeti-kaliningrada-konkuruos-su-lietuva-ir-lenkija.htm „Gazprom“ nutarė gelbėti Kaliningradą. Konkuruos su Lietuva ir Lenkija]</ref>
===Thailand=== *Map Ta Phut LNG Terminal/ Project expansion for Phase 2.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
===Ukraine=== *Proposed terminal near [[Odessa]], on 26 November 2012 the [[Ukrainian government]] and [[Unión Fenosa]] (where believed to have) signed an agreement on its building but Unión Fenosa denies this and it claimed on 28 November 2012 "nor are we leading any consortium to develop such a terminal ... nor are we studying anything along these lines".<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/riddle-persists-of-ukraine-gas-deal-that-never-was-317245.html Riddle persists of Ukraine gas deal that-never-was], [[Kyiv Post]] (6 December 2012)</ref><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/11/29/us-ukraine-gas-lng-idUSBRE8AS0W720121129 Ukraine contacts Spanish firm after $1 billion gas deal fiasco], [[Reuters]] (29 November 2012)</ref> The terminal was due to start working at a capacity of 5 billion [[cubic meters]] a year by 2016.<ref>[http://en.ria.ru/business/20121126/177741743.html Kiev Sets up $856 Mln LNG Terminal Consortium], [[RIA Novosti]] (26 November 2012)</ref>
===United States and Gulf of Mexico=== Proposed LNG Terminals:<ref>[http://ferc.gov/industries/gas/indus-act/lng/lng-proposed.pdf Proposed North American LNG Import Terminals] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101005165733/http://ferc.gov/industries/gas/indus-act/lng/lng-proposed.pdf |date=5 October 2010 }} - [[FERC]] (Adobe Reader .PDF document)</ref>
*[[Broadwater Energy]], proposed floating terminal in [[Long Island Sound]] between [[New York State]] and [[Connecticut]] *[[BlueOcean Energy]], 20 miles off-shore from New Jersey<ref>[http://www.blueoceanenergy.com BlueOcean Energy]</ref> *[[Bradwood Landing]], east of [[Astoria, Oregon]], on the Columbia River<ref>[http://www.bradwoodlanding.com/]</ref> *Oregon LNG, proposed for a site in Warrenton, just west of [[Astoria, Oregon]] on the Columbia River<ref>[http://www.oregonlng.com/]</ref> *AES Sparrows Point LNG near [[Baltimore]], Maryland<ref>[http://www.aessparrowspointlng.com/ Sparrows Point website]</ref> *Cabrillo Port Liquefied Natural Gas Deepwater Port, proposed [[FSRU]] terminal approximately 21 miles offshore of Port Hueneme, Ventura County, California<ref>[https://www.bhp.com/-/media/bhp/documents/investors/news/brochcabllprtfd.pdf?la=en/ BHP website]</ref>. disapproved by Gov. [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] on May 18th, 2007<ref>[https://archive.epa.gov/region9/nepa/web/pdf/cabrillodeepwaterport-feis.pdf/ EPA website]</ref><ref>[https://www.marad.dot.gov/ports/office-of-deepwater-ports-and-offshore-activities/withdrawn-and-disapproved-applications/ MARAD website]</ref>. *Downeast LNG on Passamaquoddy Bay, Robbinston, Maine<ref>[http://www.downeastlng.com/ Downeast LNG website]</ref> As of 6 January 2010, Downeast LNG will be one-and-one-half years late in supplying answers to FERC's technical questions arising from the Draft Environmental Impact Statement. FERC's deadline was 6 July 2009. *Aguirre GasPort LNG Terminal in [[Salinas, Puerto Rico]]<ref>[http://caribbeanbusinesspr.com/news03.php?nt_id=66202&ct_id=1&ct_name=1]</ref> *[[Jordan Cove Energy Project]], Coos Bay, Oregon<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ferc.gov/industries/gas/indus-act/lng/LNG-proposed-potential.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120417091656/http://www.ferc.gov/industries/gas/indus-act/lng/LNG-proposed-potential.pdf |archivedate=17 April 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==See also== * [[CNOOC#LNG terminals]] * [[List of natural gas pipelines]]
11.http://www.lngglobal.com/latest/sabine-pass-progress-report-train-2-first-cargo-mid-august-2016.html ==References== {{reflist|2}} <!-- ==External links== -->
{{Fuel Transport}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}}

page.title: List of smart TV platforms and middleware software

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Technological comparison to [[:Category:Technological comparisons]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
The following list encompasses notable [[smart TV]] platforms and [[application software]] that are used as [[software framework]] and [[middleware]] platforms used by more than just one manufacturer.
{{Main|Smart TV}}
==Smart TV middleware providers to multiple third parties== For TV sets and companion boxes vendors, available under OEM license.
===Smart TV framework platforms managed by standardization bodies or technology consortium=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Framework !! Managed by !! Comments |- | [[Hybrid Broadcast Broadband TV|HbbTV]] || HbbTV Association || An [[HTML5]]-based application framework middle-ware software platform provided by the Hybrid Broadcast Broadband TV association. |- | [[CE-HTML]] || [[Consumer Electronics Association|CEA (Consumer Electronics Association)]] || As part of Web4CE. |- | [[OIPF]] || [[Open IPTV Forum]] || As of June 2014, OIPF is now part of the [[Hybrid Broadcast Broadband TV|HbbTV]] Association. |- | [[Tru2way]] || [[CableLabs]] || |}
===Smart TV framework platforms managed by single companies or foundations===
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Framework !! Managed by !! Used by || Comment |- | [[Android TV]] || [[Google]] || Asus
AT&T (DirecTV)
Bang & Olufsen
Bouygues Telecom (Bbox Miami)
CCC Mobile (Air Stick)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://japan.cnet.com/article/35093972/ |title=The world's smallest Android TV Air Stick |publisher=CNET JAPAN |date=December 19, 2016 |accessdate=October 25, 2017}}</ref>
ChannelMaster
Dish
Free/Iliad (Freebox Mini 4K)
Hisense
Grundig
LeEco (Super4 X Series)
NVIDIA (Shield TV Console)
Philips
RCA
Sharp
Skyworth
Sony
TCL/Thomson
Toshiba
Xiaomi (Mi Box) || Smart TV platform for TV sets and set-top-boxes. Gives access to Android apps through the Play Store. |- | [[Boxee]] || Boxee, Inc || D-Link || Popular [[Fork (software development)|fork]] of the [[Kodi (software)|Kodi/XBMC]] media center software with custom [[graphical user interface]] and some [[Proprietary software|proprietary]] [[application framework]] for [[Application software|apps]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://scoop.intel.com/ibc-2011-smart-tv-qa-with-iomega-olivier-deternod/ |title=IBC 2011: Smart TV Q&A with iomega’s Olivier D’Eternod |publisher=Scoop.intel.com |date=September 15, 2011 |accessdate=January 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120102011951/http://scoop.intel.com/ibc-2011-smart-tv-qa-with-iomega-olivier-deternod/ |archivedate=January 2, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldtvpc.com/blog/boxee-online-tv-moving-computer-mobile-connected-devices/ |title=Boxee See Internet TV Moving Away From The Computer To Mobile And Connected TV |publisher=Worldtvpc.com |date=December 29, 2011 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref> |- | [[Amazon Fire TV|Fire TV]] || [[Amazon Video|Amazon]] || Westinghouse, Element || Smart TV platform for TV sets |- | [[Firefox OS]] for TV || Mozilla || Panasonic || Panasonic's Smart TVs, including their new 4K TVs, continue to feature Mozilla's open source Firefox OS, despite Mozilla lowering its development priority on developing the operating system. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trustedreviews.com/news/panasonic-sticks-with-firefox-os-for-smart-tv-range | title=Panasonic Sticks With Firefox OS for Smart TV Range}}</ref> Panasonic is continuing to develop their fork, calling it My Home Screen while Mozilla has stated that they will continue to support and work with Panasonic<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.mozilla.org/futurereleases/2016/02/04/next-steps-for-connected-devices/ | title=Next Steps for Connected Devices}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnews.com.au/ces-2017-panasonic-announces-new-oled-tv-and-4k-blu-ray-players/ | title=Panasonic Announces New OLED TV and 4K Blu Ray Players}}</ref> |- | Frog || [[Wyplay]] || SFR || Used by some IPTV operators, such as SFR in France on its set-top-box |- | [[Google TV]] || Google || Asus
Hisense
LG
Logitech
Netgear
SFR
Sony
TCL
Vizio || [[Android (operating system)|Android]] based platform.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.linuxfordevices.com/c/a/News/Google-TV-2-rolls-out/ |title=Google TV 2.0 gains Honeycomb, Android Market |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120905214746/http://www.linuxfordevices.com/c/a/News/Google-TV-2-rolls-out/ |archivedate=2012-09-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Its development stopped in 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=https://code.google.com/p/googletv-issues/issues/list|title=Googletv issue tracker}}</ref> and it is replaced by [[Chromecast]] and [[Android TV]]. |- | [[Liberty Global#Horizon TV|Horizon TV]] || [[Liberty Global]] || || A cross-platform platform based [[Fork (software development)|fork]] of the [[Kodi (software)|Kodi/XBMC]] media center software with proprietary middleware framework for video on demand and handling DRM for streaming cable television channels. |- | httvLink || [[HTTV]] || Kaon Pace
Sagemcom
Smit || An HbbTV compliant TV Operating System for Connected TV receivers, addressing all Digital TV platforms. |- | Inview || [[Inview Technology Ltd]] || Digifusion Thomson
Sony || Connects an ordinary TV (or set-top box) to get [[IPTV]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Smith |first=Tony |url=http://www.reghardware.com/2012/01/23/iptv_week_acetrax_signs_up_for_inview_settop_box_ui/ |title= Acetrax joins Inview VoD squad |date=23 January 2012 | accessdate=8 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.digitaltveurope.net/19750/acetrax--to--launch--online--movie--service--with--inview--platform/ |title=Acetrax to launch online movie service with Inview platform |date=2011 |publisher=DigitalTV.net |accessdate=2012-08-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304094902/http://www.digitaltveurope.net/19750/acetrax--to--launch--online--movie--service--with--inview--platform/ |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref> |- | [[Kodi (software)|Kodi Entertainment Center]] (formerly XBMC Media Center) || XBMC Foundation || || Open source cross-platform media center and DVR/PVR frontend software. |- | [[MeeGo]] || [[Nokia]], [[The Linux Foundation]] || || Middleware for [[smart TV]]. Now split into [[Tizen]], [[Mer (software distribution)|Mer]], and [[Sailfish OS]])<ref>https://meego.com/devices/smart-tv MeeGo for Smart TV</ref> ([[Linux Foundation]], [[Intel Corporation|Intel]], revision.text:
{{globalize/UK|date=December 2010}} '''Local eGovernment''' is [[eGovernment]] as it relates to [[local government]], police, fire, national park and transport authorities.
== Local eGovernment in England == The [[UK government]]’s objective was that all of public services in [[England]] should be capable of being delivered electronically by 31 December 2005. The ''Modernising Government'' White Paper of March 1999 proposed "all dealings with government being deliverable electronically by 2008." Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] then announced on 30 March 2000 that the target date had been brought forward from 2008 to 2005.
Electronic delivery is defined as delivery through internet protocols and other ICT methods and includes delivery by telephone if the officer receiving the call can access electronic information and/or update records online there and then.
The average local authority achieved a reported 97% e-enablement by 31 December 2005, though it is suspected the actual figure is much lower. The target also applied to the Civil Service, which achieved a reported 96%.
=== Objectives and performance management === ==== Implementing Electronic Government (IEG) Statements ==== From December 2001 to April 2006 local authorities were required to publish an ''IEG Statement'' on their degree of e-enablement (electronic enablement). The measures include BVPI 157 and the Priority Outcomes.
==== Best Value Performance Indicator (BVPI) 157 ==== BVPI 157 measures the percentage of 'interactions' provided by a local authority that are e-enabled. The figure must be published annually as part of the Best Value performance management framework. The figure is calculated by considering the following ten types of interaction as they apply to the services provided by the local authority: *providing information *collecting revenue *providing benefits and grants *consultation *regulation (such as issuing licences) *applications for services *booking venues, resources and courses *paying for goods and services *providing access to community, professional or business networks *procurement Local authorities may use a proprietary list of services, but are required to validate their list against the ''Local Government Services List'' (LGSL). BVPI 157 forms part of the annual IEG statement.
==== Priority Outcomes ==== To guide local authorities in implementing eGovernment, the Department for Transport, Local Government and the Regions (and its successor the Office of the Deputy Prime Minister (ODPM)) issued a list of key targets, most commonly referred to as the Priority Outcomes or PSOs (Priority Service Outcomes). The list was issued in the snappily entitled document ''Defining E-government Outcomes for 2005 to Support the Delivery of Priority Services & National Strategy Transformation Agenda for Local Authorities in England – Version 1.0''. In September 2004, detailed guidance on the Priority Outcomes was issued in the document ''Priority Outcomes - Explanatory Notes for Practitioners'', published by the IDeA (Improvement and Development Agency) and endorsed by the ODPM.
Priority Outcomes are rated with three levels of obligation: *''Required'' = To be implemented (available for use) by Dec 2005 *''Good'' = To be approved for funding and being actively implemented by Dec 2005 and implemented by April 1, 2006 *''Excellent'' = Voluntary for authorities that have implemented required and good outcomes early.
The following technologies are recommended in Priority Outcomes: Explanatory Notes for Practitioners as those likely to be essential in the achievement of the Priority Outcomes: *[[Customer relationship management]] system: **Customer database (single view of info on each customer, citizen and business) **Customer tracking (across access channels and from contact to resolution) **Data warehousing (central repository for data, including legacy data) *[[Middleware]] and [[web services]] (manages flow of data between all systems, including external) *[[Document management system]]: **Workflow, messaging and e-forms (gets work to the right people at the right time) **Document and records management (e-storage of all documents and info) *[[Content management]] (system for publishing of content to all access channels) *Security, [[authentication]] and [[smartcard]]s (for security of information) *e-Payments (system for receiving payments to the council) *[[e-procurement|e-Procurement]] (system for internal/external buying processes) *[[Geographic information system|Geographic Information System]] (GIS) (access to geographical data through maps) *Local land and property gazetteer (database of land and property information) *Access channels (websites, call centres, [[internet kiosk|kiosks]], [[digital TV]], mobile phones, etc.)
==== Socitm Insight Better Connected reports ==== Local authority websites are also subject to assessments by Socitm (Society of Information Technology Management) Insight in their annual ''Better Connected'' reports.
== References == [https://web.archive.org/web/20090810202035/http://www.archive.official-documents.co.uk/document/cm43/4310/4310.htm Modernising Government White Paper, March 1999] on the Official-Documents.gov.uk website
[https://web.archive.org/web/20051031130825/http://www.idea-knowledge.gov.uk/idk/core/page.do?pageId=1704073 Priority Outcomes - Explanatory Notes for Practitioners] on the IDeA website
[https://web.archive.org/web/20051028044200/http://www.odpm.gov.uk/pns/pnattach/20040112/1.doc Defining E-government Outcomes for 2005 to Support the Delivery of Priority Services & National Strategy Transformation Agenda for Local Authorities in England – Version 1.0] (Microsoft Word document) on the ODPM website
[http://www.esd.org.uk/standards/ Local Government Services List] and related information on the Electronic Service Delivery website.
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20041122191056/http://www.odpm.gov.uk/ ODPM (Office of the Deputy Prime Minister) website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040507032849/http://www.idea-knowledge.gov.uk/ IDeA (Improvement and Development Agency) website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051201000036/http://www.socitm.gov.uk/public/insight/ Socitm Insight website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051013070911/http://www.direct.gov.uk/Dl1/Directories/LocalCouncils/fs/en Listings of local authorities and their websites] on the Directgov website *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060502010923/http://www.esd.org.uk/esdtoolkit/ ESD Toolkit] by the I&DeA for measuring BVPI 157 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110615070253/http://www.tfa.net/files/madeleinewestropmarch2009.pdf] criticism of eGovernment * [http://www.microsoft.com/industry/government/guides/Gov20.aspx Microsoft Government 2.0 software]
==See also== * [[Information Kerala Mission]]

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Ludites}} {{for|the EP by Grotus|Luddite (EP)}} {{Use British English|date=March 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} [[File:Luddite.jpg|thumb|250px|''The Leader of the Luddites'', engraving of 1812]]
The '''Luddites''' were a secret oath-based organization<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thebaffler.com/latest/a-nod-to-ned-ludd|title=A nod to Ned Ludd|accessdate=6 November 2018}}</ref> of [[England|English]] textile workers in the 19th century, where a radical faction destroyed textile machinery as a form of protest. The group was protesting the use of machinery in a "fraudulent and deceitful manner" to get around standard labour practices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/what-the-luddites-really-fought-against-264412/?no-ist=&page=2|title=What the Luddites Really Fought Against|accessdate=8 December 2016}}</ref> Luddites feared correctly that the time spent learning the skills of their craft would go to waste as machines would replace their role in the industry.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.history.com/news/ask-history/who-were-the-luddites|title=Who were the Luddites? |newspaper=History.com|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref> It is a misconception that the Luddites protested against the machinery itself in an attempt to halt the progress of technology. Over time, however, the term has come to mean one opposed to [[industrialisation]], [[automation]], [[embedded computer system|computerisation,]] or new [[technology|technologies]] in general.<ref>[http://www.askoxford.com/results/?view=dev_dict&field-12668446=luddite&branch=13842570&textsearchtype=exact&sortorder=score%2Cname "Luddite"] ''Compact Oxford English Dictionary'' at AskOxford.com. Accessed February 22, 2010.</ref> The Luddite movement began in [[Nottingham]] and culminated in a region-wide rebellion that lasted from 1811 to 1816. Mill and factory owners took to shooting protesters and eventually the movement was suppressed with military force.
== Etymology ==
Although the origin of the name Luddite ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|l|ʌ|d|.|aɪ|t}}) is uncertain, the movement was said to be named after [[Ned Ludd]], an apprentice who allegedly smashed two [[stocking frame]]s in 1779 and whose name had become emblematic of machine destroyers. Ned Ludd, however, was completely fictional and used as a way to shock and provoke the government.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20160205162901/http://www.leicesteruk.net/historydetail.php?id=13322&f= Anstey at Welcome to Leicester (visitoruk.com)] According to this source, "A half-witted Anstey lad, Ned Ludlam or Ned Ludd, gave his name to the Luddites, who in the 1800s followed his earlier example by expressing violence against machinery in protest against the Industrial Revolution."</ref><ref name="Palmer">Palmer, Roy, 1998, ''The Sound of History: Songs and Social Comment'', [[Oxford University Press]], {{ISBN|978-0-19-215890-1}}, p. 103</ref><ref name="Chambers">Chambers, Robert (2004), ''Book of Days: A Miscellany of Popular Antiquities in Connection with the Calendar, Part 1'', Kessinger, {{ISBN|978-0-7661-8338-4}}, p. 357</ref> The name evolved into the imaginary General Ludd or King Ludd, who, like [[Robin Hood]], was reputed to live in [[Sherwood Forest]].<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/education/politics/g3/ |publisher=The National Archives |accessdate=19 August 2011 |title=The National Archives Learning Curve | Power, Politics and Protest | the Luddites}}</ref>{{efn|Historian [[Eric Hobsbawm]] has called their machine wrecking "[[collective bargaining]] by riot", which had been a tactic used in Britain since the [[Restoration (England)|Restoration]], as the scattering of manufactories throughout the country made large-scale strikes impractical.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://libcom.org/history/machine-breakers-eric-hobsbawm |author= Hobsbawm, Eric |title= 'The Machine Breakers', Past and Present 1 (1952), 57–70 |publisher= Libcom.org |date= 2009-07-04 |accessdate= 2013-10-04}}</ref><ref name="econ-www.mit.edu">Author, Frank; Levy, David and Murnane, Richard J. [http://econ-www.mit.edu/files/569 "The Skill Content of Recent Technological Change: An Empirical Exploration"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100315142837/http://econ-www.mit.edu/files/569 |date=15 March 2010 }} ''Quarterly Journal of Economics'' (2003)</ref>}}
== Historical precedents ==
The lower classes of the 18th century, generally speaking, were not openly disloyal to the king or government.<ref name="Wearmouth1945">{{cite book|author=Robert Featherstone Wearmouth|title=Methodism and the common people of the eighteenth century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O1w3AAAAMAAJ|accessdate=21 April 2013|year=1945|publisher=Epworth Press|page=51}}</ref> Overall, violent action was rare because punishments were harsh. The majority of individuals were primarily concerned with meeting their own daily needs.<ref>R. F. Wearmouth, ''Methodism and the Common People of the Eighteenth Century''. (1945), esp. chs. 1 and 2.</ref> This movement towards aggression in the 19th century can be seen as part of the rise in English working-class discontent due to the Industrial Revolution. Working conditions in the mills were harsh but efficient enough to threaten the livelihoods of skilled artisans. The new inventions allowed for faster and cheaper labour because machines were operated by less-skilled, low-wage labourers. The Luddites were not afraid of technology and did not attempt to eliminate technology out of fear. Their goal was instead to gain a better bargaining position with their employers.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Merchant|first1=Brian|title=You've Got Luddites All Wrong|url=http://motherboard.vice.com/en_ca/read/luddites-definition-wrong-labor-technophobe|publisher=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref> Luddism was in fact a prototypical, insurrectionary labour movement involving a loose coalition of dissenters.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://motherboard.vice.com/read/luddites-definition-wrong-labor-technophobe|title=You've Got Luddites All Wrong|newspaper=Motherboard|language=en-us|access-date=2016-11-22}}</ref>
Research by Kevin Binfield and others asserts that since organized action by [[stockinger (occupation)|stockingers]] had occurred at various times since 1675, the movements of the early 19th century must be viewed in the context of the hardships suffered by the working class during the [[Napoleonic Wars]], rather than as an absolute aversion to machinery.<ref>{{cite book|last=Binfield|first=Kevin|title=Luddites and Luddism|year=2004|publisher=The Johns Hopkins University Press|location=Baltimore and London}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Rude|first=George|title=The Crowd in History: A Study of Popular Disturbances in France and England, 1730–1848|year=2001|publisher=Serif}}</ref><ref name=thomis/> Irregular rises in food prices provoked [[Keelmen|the Keelmen]] working in the [[port of Tyne]] to riot in 1710<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=43320 |title=Historical events – 1685–1782 | Historical Account of Newcastle-upon-Tyne (pp. 47–65) |publisher=British-history.ac.uk |date=2003-06-22 |accessdate=2013-10-04}}</ref> and tin miners to steal from granaries at [[Falmouth, Cornwall|Falmouth]] in 1727. There was a rebellion in [[Northumberland]] and [[Durham, England|Durham]] in 1740, and the assault of Quaker corn dealers in 1756. Skilled artisans in the cloth, building, shipbuilding, printing and cutlery trades organized friendly societies to peacefully insure themselves against unemployment, sickness, and in some cases against intrusion of "foreign" labour into their trades, as was common among guilds.<ref name="Charles Wilson 1965 p. 344-5">Charles Wilson, England's Apprenticeship, 1603-1763 (1965), pp. 344–45. PRO, SP 36/4/22.</ref>{{efn| The Falmouth magistrates reported to the Duke of Newcastle (16 Nov. 1727) that "the unruly tinners" had "broke open and plundered several cellars and granaries of corn." Their report concludes with a comment that suggests that they were no more able than some modern historians to understand the rationale of the direct action of the tinners: "the occasion of these outrages was pretended by the rioters to be a scarcity of corn in the county, but this suggestion is probably false, as most of those who carried off the corn gave it away or sold it at quarter price." PRO, SP 36/4/22.}}
Malcolm L. Thomis argued in his 1970 history, ''The Luddites'', that without the structure of a union, machine-breaking was one of very few mechanisms workers could use to increase pressure on employers, to undermine lower-paid competing workers and to create solidarity among workers, "These attacks on machines did not imply any necessary hostility to machinery as such; machinery was just a conveniently exposed target against which an attack could be made."<ref name="thomis">{{cite book|last=Thomis|first=Malcolm|title=The Luddites: Machine Breaking in Regency England|year=1970|publisher=Shocken}}</ref>
An agricultural variant of Luddism, centering on the breaking of threshing machines, occurred during the widespread [[Swing Riots]] of 1830 in southern and eastern England.<ref name="harrison249">Harrison. The Common People. pp. 249–53</ref>
== Birth of the movement == :''See also [[Barthélemy Thimonnier]], whose sewing machines were destroyed by tailors who believed that their jobs were threatened''
The Luddite movement emerged during the harsh economic climate of the [[Napoleonic Wars]], which saw a rise of difficult working conditions in the new textile factories. Luddites objected primarily to the rising popularity of automated textile equipment, threatening the jobs and livelihoods of skilled workers as this technology allowed them to be replaced by cheaper and less skilled workers.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/what-the-luddites-really-fought-against-264412/?all|title=What the Luddites Really Fought Against|last=Conniff|first=Richard|newspaper=Smithsonian|access-date=2016-10-19}}</ref> The movement began in [[Arnold, Nottinghamshire|Arnold]], [[Nottingham]] on 11 March 1811 and spread rapidly throughout England over the following two years.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Beckett|first1=John|title=Luddites|url=http://www.nottsheritagegateway.org.uk/people/luddites.htm|website=The Nottinghamshire Heritage Gateway|publisher=[[Thoroton Society of Nottinghamshire]]|accessdate=2 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=Conniff>{{cite web|last=Conniff|first=Richard|title=What the Luddites Really Fought Against|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history-archaeology/What-the-Luddites-Really-Fought-Against.html?c=y&page=2|work=smithsonianmag.com|accessdate=18 June 2013}}</ref> [[Loom#Handloom|Handloom]] weavers burned mills and pieces of factory machinery. Textile workers destroyed industrial equipment during the late 18th century,<ref name=":0" /> prompting acts such as the [[Protection of Stocking Frames, etc. Act 1788]].
The Luddites met at night on the moors surrounding industrial towns to practice drills and maneuvers. Their main areas of operation began in [[Nottinghamshire]] in November 1811, followed by the [[West Riding of Yorkshire]] in early 1812 then [[Lancashire]] by March 1813. They smashed [[stocking frame]]s and cropping frames among others. There does not seem to have been any political motivation behind the Luddite riots and there was no national organization. The men were merely attacking what they saw as the reason for the decline in their livelihoods.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.victorianweb.org/history/riots/luddites.html|title=The Luddites 1811-1816|website=www.victorianweb.org|access-date=2016-11-22}}</ref> Luddites battled the British Army at Burton's Mill in [[Middleton, Greater Manchester|Middleton]] and at [[Westhoughton Mill]], both in Lancashire.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Radicalism and Reform in Britain, 1780–1850|last = Dinwiddy|first = J.R.|publisher = Hambledon Press|year = 1992|isbn = |location = London|pages = 371–401|work = |chapter = Luddism and Politics in the Northern Counties|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=hI2tAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA371&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=3#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> The Luddites and their supporters anonymously sent death threats to, and possibly attacked, magistrates and food merchants. Activists smashed Heathcote's lacemaking machine in Loughborough in 1816.{{sfn|Sale|1995|p=188}} He and other industrialists had secret chambers constructed in their buildings that could be used as hiding places during an attack.<ref>{{cite news|title=Workmen discover secret chambers|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/leicestershire/4791069.stm|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=31 December 2012}}</ref>
In 1817, an unemployed Nottingham [[stockinger (occupation)|stockinger]] and probably ex-Luddite, named [[Jeremiah Brandreth]] led the [[Pentrich Rising]]. While this was a general uprising unrelated to machinery, it can be viewed as the last major Luddite act.
== Government response == [[File:FrameBreaking-1812.jpg|thumb|Later interpretation of machine breaking (1812), showing two men superimposed on an 1844 engraving from the Penny magazine which shows a post 1820s [[Jacquard loom]].{{efn|[[:File:The Penny Magazine 1844, p.33.jpg|The Penny Magazine 1844, p.33]]}} Machine-breaking was criminalised by the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]] as early as 1721, the penalty being [[penal transportation]], but as a result of continued opposition to mechanisation the [[Frame Breaking Act|Frame Breaking Act 1812]] made the [[death penalty]] available: see "[[criminal damage in English law]]".]]
The [[British Army]] clashed with the Luddites on several occasions. At one time there were more British soldiers fighting the Luddites than there were fighting [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon]] on the [[Iberian Peninsula]].<ref>[[Eric Hobsbawm|Hobsbawm, Eric]] (1964) "The Machine Breakers" in ''Labouring Men. Studies in the History of Labour.'', London, Weidenfeld and Nicolson, page 6</ref>{{efn| Hobsbawm has popularized this comparison and refers to the original statement in [[Frank Ongley Darvall]] (1969) ''Popular Disturbances and Public Order in Regency England'', London, Oxford University Press, p. 260.}} Three Luddites, led by George Mellor, ambushed and assassinated mill owner William Horsfall of Ottiwells Mill in [[Marsden, West Yorkshire]] at [[Crosland Moor]] in [[Huddersfield]]. Horsfall had remarked that he would "Ride up to his saddle in Luddite blood."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yGkTDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT14&lpg=PT14&dq=Horsfall++%22Ride+up+to+his+saddle+in+Luddite+blood.%22&source=bl&ots=Q1ZRIoshVP&sig=jiXoHzguYZ07yXCvzbLC6q1qf84&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiT_ePGhO_QAhXBwiYKHZ1eCYQQ6AEILTAD#v=onepage&q=Horsfall%20%20%22Ride%20up%20to%20his%20saddle%20in%20Luddite%20blood.%22&f=false|title=Grim Almanac of York|last=Sharp|first=Alan|date=2015-05-04|publisher=The History Press|isbn=9780750964562|language=en}}</ref> Mellor fired the fatal shot to Horsfall's groin, and all three men were arrested.
[[Lord Byron]] denounced what he considered to be the plight of the working class, the government’s inane policies and ruthless repression in the [[House of Lords]] on 27 February 1812: "I have been in some of the most oppressed provinces of [[Turkey]]; but never, under the most despotic of infidel governments, did I behold such squalid wretchedness as I have seen since my return, in the very heart of a Christian country."<ref>Lord Byron, Debate on the 1812 Framework Bill, [[Hansard]], http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/lords/1812/feb/27/frame-work-bill#S1V0021P0_18120227_HOL_7</ref>
The [[British government]] sought to suppress the Luddite movement with a mass trial at [[York]] in January 1813, following the attack on Cartwrights mill at Rawfolds near Cleckheaton. The government charged over 60 men, including Mellor and his companions, with various crimes in connection with Luddite activities. While some of those charged were actual Luddites, many had no connection to the movement. Although the proceedings were legitimate jury trials, many were abandoned due to lack of evidence and 30 men were acquitted. These trials were certainly intended to act as [[show trials]] to deter other Luddites from continuing their activities. The harsh sentences of those found guilty, which included [[execution]] and [[penal transportation]], quickly ended the movement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marsdenhistory.co.uk/people/luddites.html#link4 |title=Luddites in Marsden: Trials at York |accessdate=May 12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326170835/http://www.marsdenhistory.co.uk/people/luddites.html |archivedate=26 March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>Elizabeth Gaskell: The Life of Charlotte Bronte, Vol. 1, Ch. 6, for contemporaneous description of attack on Cartwright.</ref>
Parliament made "machine breaking" (i.e. industrial [[sabotage]]) a [[capital crime]] with the [[Destruction of Stocking Frames, etc. Act 1812|Frame Breaking Act]] of 1812<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=8adFAAAAcAAJ&dq=%22destruction%22%20%22stocking-frames%22%20parliamentary&pg=PA633#v=onepage&q&f=false "Destruction of Stocking Frames, etc. Act 1812"] at books.google.com</ref> and the [[Malicious Damage Act 1861]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=QT0WAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA441&lpg=PA441&dq=%22The+Malicious+Damage+Act,+1812%22&source=bl&ots=-F1DpPC2wC&sig=NAiGxV3cz3dUAjVXvvyvtQvnlg8&hl=en&ei=EE3UTZO7GOjhiAKTrsHEAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBsQ6AEwAA "The Malicious Damage Act, 1812] at books.google.com</ref> [[George Gordon Byron, 6th Baron Byron|Lord Byron]] opposed this legislation, becoming one of the few prominent defenders of the Luddites after the treatment of the defendants at the York trials.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldsocialism.org/spgb/socialist-standard/2010s/2011/no-1282-june-2011/lord-byron-and-luddites|title=Lord Byron and the Luddites {{!}} The Socialist Party of Great Britain|website=www.worldsocialism.org|access-date=2016-11-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160624121100/http://www.worldsocialism.org/spgb/socialist-standard/2010s/2011/no-1282-june-2011/lord-byron-and-luddites#|archive-date=24 June 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Coincidently, Lord Byron's only legitimate daughter [[Ada Lovelace]] would become the first computer programmer by combining the technology of the [[Analytical Engine]] with the [[Jacquard loom]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Plant|first=Sadie|date=November 1, 1995|title=The Future Looms: Weaving Women and Cybernetics|url=|journal=Body & Society|volume=1|pages=45-64|via=Sage Publications}}</ref>.
== Legacy == {{anchor|In retrospect}} In 1867 [[Karl Marx]] wrote that it would be some time before workers were able to distinguish between the machines and "the form of society which utilizes these instruments" and their ideas. "The instrument of labour, when it takes the form of a machine, immediately becomes a competitor of the workman himself."<ref>[https://www.marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1867-c1/ch15.htm#S5 Karl Marx, Capital Vol. I, Ch. 15, Sect. 5].</ref>
In the 19th century, occupations that arose from the growth of trade and shipping in ports, also in 'domestic' manufacturers, were notorious for precarious employment prospects. Underemployment was chronic during this period,<ref name="Charles Wilson 1965 p. 344-5"/> and it was common practice to retain a larger workforce than was typically necessary for insurance against labour shortages in boom times.<ref name="Charles Wilson 1965 p. 344-5"/>
Moreover, the organization of manufacture by merchant-capitalists in the textile industry was inherently unstable. While the financiers' capital was still largely invested in raw material, it was easy to increase commitment where trade was good and almost as easy to cut back when times were bad. Merchant-capitalists lacked the incentive of later factory owners, whose capital was invested in building and plants, to maintain a steady rate of production and return on fixed capital. The combination of seasonal variations in wage rates and violent short-term fluctuations springing from harvests and war, periodic outbreaks of violence are more easily understood.<ref name="Charles Wilson 1965 p. 344-5"/>
== Modern usage ==
In 1956, a speech said that "organized workers were by no means wedded to a Luddite Philosophy."{{sfn|Sale|1995|p = 205}} More recently, the term [[Neo-Luddism]] has emerged to describe opposition to many forms of technology.<ref name="jonesagainstechnology">{{cite book | last = Jones | first = Steve E. | title = Against technology: from the Luddites to neo-Luddism | publisher = CRC Press | year = 2006 | location = | page = 20 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=YwPP4pGRAwgC&dq=Neo-Luddism| isbn = 978-0-415-97868-2}}</ref> According to a manifesto drawn up by the Second Luddite Congress (April 1996; Barnesville, Ohio), Neo-Luddism is "a leaderless movement of passive resistance to consumerism and the increasingly bizarre and frightening technologies of the Computer Age."<ref name="Sale">Sale, Kirkpatrick, America's new Luddites. URL=http://mondediplo.com/1997/02/20luddites</ref>
The term “[[Luddite fallacy]]” is used by economists in reference to the fear that [[technological unemployment]] inevitably generates [[structural unemployment]] and is consequently macroeconomically injurious. If a technological innovation results in a reduction of necessary labour inputs in a given sector, then the industry-wide cost of production falls, which lowers the competitive price and increases the equilibrium supply point which, theoretically, will require an increase in aggregate labour inputs.<ref>{{ cite book | last1 = Jerome | first1 = Harry | author1-link = | title = Mechanization in Industry, National Bureau of Economic Research | year = 1934 | url = http://papers.nber.org/books/jero34-1 | pages = 32–35 }}</ref>
== See also == * [[Development criticism]] * [[Simple living]] * [[Technophobia]] * [[Turner Controversy]] – return to [[pre-industrial]] methods of production * [[Ruddington#Museums|Ruddington Framework Knitters' Museum]] – features a Luddite gallery

== Further reading == <!-- To add a new reference, please use the following template: * {{Cite book|author=|title=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|url=}}--> * {{Cite book|author=Archer, John E.|chapter=Chapter 4: Industrial Protest|title=Social unrest and popular protest in England, 1780–1840|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2000|isbn=978-0-521-57656-7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pb0RzCN-ipMC}} * {{Cite book|author=Bailey, Brian J|title=The Luddite Rebellion|publisher=NYU Press|year=1998|isbn=0-8147-1335-1|url=}} * {{Cite book|author=Binfield, Kevin|title=Writings of the Luddites|publisher=JHU Press|year=2004|isbn=0-8018-7612-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NG6ABlDQ10MC}} * {{Cite book|author=Fox, Nicols|title=Against the Machine: The Hidden Luddite History in Literature, Art, and Individual Lives|publisher=Island Press|year=2003|isbn=1-55963-860-5|url=}} * {{Cite book|author1=Grint, Keith |author2=Woolgar, Steve |lastauthoramp=yes |chapter=The Luddites: ''Diablo ex Machina''|title=The machine at work: technology, work, and organization|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|year=1997|isbn=978-0-7456-0924-9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HjijdK2VwWQC&pg=PA39}} * {{Cite book|author=Jones, Steven E.|title=Against technology: from the Luddites to Neo-Luddism|publisher=CRC Press|year=2006|isbn=978-0-415-97868-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YwPP4pGRAwgC}} * {{Cite article|author=Ewan McGaughey|title=Will Robots Automate Your Job Away? Full Employment, Basic Income, and Economic Democracy|publisher=ssrn.com|year=2018|isbn=|url=https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3044448}} * {{Cite book|author=Randall, Adrian|title=Before the Luddites: Custom, Community and Machinery in the English Woollen Industry, 1776–1809|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2002|isbn=978-0-521-89334-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6P_B2TeiPeYC}} * {{Cite book|author=Rude, George|chapter=Chapter 5, Luddism|title=The crowd in History, 1730–1848|publisher=Serif|year=2005|isbn=978-1-897959-47-3}} * {{Cite book|author=Sale|first= Kirkpatrick|title=Rebels against the future: the Luddites and their war on the Industrial Revolution: lessons for the computer age|publisher=Basic Books|year=1995|isbn=0-201-40718-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kNnmrkJFQ5cC|ref=harv}} * {{Cite book|author=Thompson, E. P.|authorlink=E. P. Thompson|title=The Making of the English Working Class|publisher=Penguin Books|year=1991|isbn=978-0-14-013603-6|url=http://www.penguin.co.uk/nf/Book/BookDisplay/0,,9780140136036,00.html|access-date=16 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006112241/http://www.penguin.co.uk/nf/Book/BookDisplay/0,,9780140136036,00.html|archive-date=6 October 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}
== External links == {{wikiquote}} {{Commons category|Luddism}} {{Wiktionary|Luddite}} * [http://ludditebicentenary.blogspot.co.uk Luddite Bicentenary - Comprehensive chronicle of the Luddite uprisings] * [http://www.ludditelink.org.uk/index.php The Luddite Link - Comprehensive historical resources for the original West Yorkshire Luddites, University of Huddersfield. ] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20180810121337/http://uprisingevents.org/ The Uprising Series, a series of creative events marking the bicentenary of the Luddites' uprisings in West Yorkshire, led by the Lawrence Batley Theatre, Huddersfield {{Dead link|date=February 2015}}] * [https://www.nytimes.com/books/97/05/18/reviews/pynchon-luddite.html ''Is it O.K. to be a Luddite?'' by Thomas Pynchon] * [http://carbon.ucdenver.edu/~mryder/itc_data/luddite.html ''Luddism and the Neo-Luddite Reaction'' by Martin Ryder, University of Colorado at Denver School of Education] * [http://www.marxists.org/history/england/combination-laws/index.htm The Luddites and the Combination Acts] from the Marxists Internet Archive

revision.text:
The '''MIT Center for Collective Intelligence'''<ref>[http://cci.mit.edu MIT Center for Collective Intelligence<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ('''CCI''') is a research center at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], headed by Professor [[Thomas W. Malone]], that focuses on the study of [[collective intelligence]].
The Center for Collective Intelligence brings together faculty from across MIT to conduct research on how new communications technologies are changing the way people work together. It involves people from many diverse organizations across MIT including; the [[MIT Media Lab]], the [[MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory]], the Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, the [[MIT Sloan School of Management]], and the Dalai Lama Center for 21st Century Ethics and Transformative Values.
== History and mission == CCI was founded in 2006 by professor [[Thomas W. Malone]]. To a great extent, this is a continuation of the research Malone and his colleagues have conducted at the Center for Coordination Science,<ref>[http://www.networkworld.com/community/?q=node/8836 MIT looks to give 'group think' a good name<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> as well as within initiatives such as "Inventing the Organizations of the 21st Century".
The center's mission is to find novel answers to one basic research motif: "How can people and computers be connected so that—collectively—they act more intelligently than any individuals, groups, or computers have ever done before?'"
In order to answer this question, the researchers conduct three types of research: # Collecting examples and case studies of collective intelligence applications. # Creating new examples and tools that harness the collective intelligence of people # Systematic studies and experiments
Finally, they also work on developing theories to explain the phenomena of collective-intelligence.
The center is sponsored by several corporates and non-profit organizations.<ref>http://cci.mit.edu/about/sponsors.html</ref>
== Members == Professor [[Thomas W. Malone]] is the founder and director of CCI. In addition to Malone, the faculty steering committee includes: Professor [[Randall Davis]] (Research Director, Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science), [[Alex (Sandy) Pentland]] (Toshiba Professor of Media Arts and Science and Director, Human Dynamics Group at the Media Laboratory), and [[Josh Tenenbaum]] - Paul E. Newton Associate Professor and Head, Computational Cognitive Science Group (Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences).
The advisory board includes [[Tim Berners-Lee]], [[Jimmy Wales]] and Alpheus Bingham (former CEO of [[Innocentive|Innocentive, Inc.]]). The center also has an active community of research scientists, students, scholars and other affiliates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cci.mit.edu/people/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100611041615/http://cci.mit.edu/people/index.html |archivedate=2010-06-11 |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://cci.mit.edu}}
[[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] [[Category:Technology in society]] [[Category:Information society]] [[Category:2006 establishments in Massachusetts]]
